history.content:
tbh i didn't like LADR
If you're already familiar with the basics of lin alg, LADR certainly won't hurt, but there are better books.

It's funny, but I actually really liked a book called Linear Algebra Done Wrong (titled this way mainly to mock LADR).


I feel like it gives some nice intuition for the higher level theory behind lin alg, but also goes into some really nice applications like Strang's Lin Alg textbook.

The author uploaded it here, if you want to check it out:

https://www.math.brown.edu/~treil/papers/LADW/book.pdf

-------

I personally like Prof. Givental's textbook, which can be found here: https://math.berkeley.edu/~giventh/11016.html

-------

I suppose it depends on what you're looking for in a textbook.

Givental's is pretty much completely geared towards the pure mathematician - something that few other textbooks set out to do, and fewer actually achieve.

tbh i didn't like LADR
If you're already familiar with the basics of lin alg, LADR certainly won't hurt, but there are better books.

It's funny, but I actually really liked a book called Linear Algebra Done Wrong (titled this way mainly to mock LADR).


I feel like it gives some nice intuition for the higher level theory behind lin alg, but also goes into some really nice applications like Strang's Lin Alg textbook.

The author uploaded it here, if you want to check it out:

https://www.math.brown.edu/~treil/papers/LADW/book.pdf

If you're really interested in the application side of linear algebra, especially with respect to CS, check out either Demmel's or Trefethen's books on Numerical Linear Algebra. 

They're used in Math 221 (Numerical Linear Algebra), and go over a lot of the application based intuition behind computational linear algebra. However, in my case (and idk if this is true for everyone), I felt like learning the intuition behind these algorithms also gave me a good understanding of the underlying mathematics.

children.subject:
Once you've done 110 the application side of 16ab is pretty much just applying knowledge to a few different formulas/procedures. If you're curious, here are the applied LA concepts in 16ab that you probably don't know - you could learn them by going through lecture notes/home works on the course websites

- Trilateration*: Determining position

- Linearization / representing linear time invariant systems as a state model in discrete / continuous time and determining controllability/observability/stability of the system.

- Singular Value Decomposition/Principal component analysis: breaks down matrices into ordered sum of most significant components, useful for data analysis

- K-means: an iterative approach to grouping data points

- Sampling and interpolation + Discrete Fourier Transforms and Linear Time Invariant systems: reconstructing a continuous signal from discrete samples. 

* This is the only 16a concept I put, as the rest of the LA content in the course is pretty generic
Whats a good way to learn more applied linear algebra, the kind used in 127/189 for someone that has taken 54/110 but not 16ab?
[Keith Conrad's notes](http://www.math.uconn.edu/~kconrad/blurbs/) are a very nice exposition of linear algebra (and more confusing) topics from a very abstract POV.

history.content:
I'm wondering whether there's a textbook I can get that covers the math 110 in more depth than Friedberg. I personally find learning the material in greater detail is the most helpful way for me to learn the concepts.

I've heard good things about Axler's "Linear Algebra Done Right", but it seems like it just teaches the material in a different way: it doesn't go into more details per se.

Thank you!
history.subject: [math 110] Linear algebra textbook in more depth?
